elements.content: On the way to copper­(I) iodide coordination polymers with specific luminescent properties, the in situ reduction of Cu­(II) in the presence of KI and bidentate N-heteroatomic ligand, either pyrazine (pyz) or 4,4′-bipyridine (bpy), resulted in one two-dimensional and two three-dimensional new coordination networks. Starting from Cu­(NO3)2·3H2O in the presence of pyz, successive precipitation of known yellow [(CuII)2(pyz)] n , new orange [CuII­(pyz)] n , and new dark blue {[CuI(pyz)2]·I5} n polymeric solids was observed. Starting from the same salt in the presence of bpy resulted in the successive precipitation of known yellow [(CuII)2(bpy)] n and new brown {[CuII(NO3)­(bpy)2]·I3·(dmf·H2O)} n coordination polymers. By using either Cu­(CH3COO)2·H2O or Cu­(BF4)2 as starting materials, both known forms, yellow [(CuII)2(bpy)] n and orange [CuII­(bpy)] n , precipitated successively. The new solids were characterized by IR spectroscopy and X-ray analysis. [CuII­(pyz)] n represents the missing member in the row of two-dimensional coordination networks with general formula [CuIX­(pyz)] n (X = Cl, Br, I). Its steady state and time-resolved characterization together with DFT and TDDFT calculations revealed that the emission at room temperature is mainly delayed fluorescence originating from mixed singlet metal-to-ligand charge transfer and halide-to-ligand charge transfer states, while that at 77 K is phosphorescence, associated with the small singlet–triplet energy differences (ΔE = 70 meV).
elements.clean_text: On the way to copper(I) iodide coordination polymers with specific luminescent properties, the in situ reduction of Cu(II) in the presence of KI and bidentate N-heteroatomic ligand, either pyrazine (pyz) or 4,4'-bipyridine (bpy), resulted in one two-dimensional and two three-dimensional new coordination networks. Starting from Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O in the presence of pyz, successive precipitation of known yellow [(CuII)2(pyz)] n , new orange [CuII(pyz)] n , and new dark blue {[CuI(pyz)2]⋅I5} n  polymeric solids was observed. Starting from the same salt in the presence of bpy resulted in the successive precipitation of known yellow [(CuII)2(bpy)] n  and new brown {[CuII(NO3)(bpy)2]⋅I3⋅(dmf⋅H2O)} n  coordination polymers. By using either Cu(CH3COO)2⋅H2O or Cu(BF4)2 as starting materials, both known forms, yellow [(CuII)2(bpy)] n  and orange [CuII(bpy)] n , precipitated successively. The new solids were characterized by IR spectroscopy and X-ray analysis. [CuII(pyz)] n  represents the missing member in the row of two-dimensional coordination networks with general formula [CuIX(pyz)] n  (X = Cl, Br, I). Its steady state and time-resolved characterization together with DFT and TDDFT calculations revealed that the emission at room temperature is mainly delayed fluorescence originating from mixed singlet metal-to-ligand charge transfer and halide-to-ligand charge transfer states, while that at 77 K is phosphorescence, associated with the small singlet-triplet energy differences (ΔE = 70 meV).

The so-far elusive member of the row [CuIX­(pyz]) n , X = Cl, Br, I, for X = I was obtained and revealed a TADF behavior in the solid state.

Introduction

The continuous interest toward Cu­(I) coordination compounds stems from their fascinating physicochemical properties that include but are not restricted to synthetic and enzymatic copper-mediated catalysis, luminescence, and nonlinear optical phenomena. The Cu­(I) d10 electronic configuration plays a prominent role in the photophysical behavior of its derivatives whose luminescence can originate from ligand-centered, charge transfer, or, in the case of polynuclear compounds, even metal-centered excited states. While interest was previously focused on the photophysical properties of discrete Cu­(I) complexes, recently research has been extended to include the emissive behavior of polymeric compounds.

Introduction

The continuous interest toward Cu(I) coordination compounds stems from their fascinating physicochemical properties that include but are not restricted to synthetic and enzymatic copper-mediated catalysis, luminescence, and nonlinear optical phenomena. The Cu(I) d10 electronic configuration plays a prominent role in the photophysical behavior of its derivatives whose luminescence can originate from ligand-centered, charge transfer, or, in the case of polynuclear compounds, even metal-centered excited states. While interest was previously focused on the photophysical properties of discrete Cu(I) complexes, recently research has been extended to include the emissive behavior of polymeric compounds.

elements.content: Cu­(I)–halide complexes are particularly attractive because of their promising optical properties and the ready obtainability of various building blocks. Cu­(I)–halides react eagerly with nitrogen-donor ligands as a result of the soft–soft bonding preference, generating diverse geometries with various [CuX] n structural motifs. Since seminal work by Blake et al. who reported a family of Cu­(I) iodide coordination networks with different bidentate ligands including 1,10-phenanthroline, pyrazine, 4,4′-bipyride, this topic has attracted much interest from the crystal engineering perspective due to the variety of structural formats obtainable by using different halides and N-bases. Cu­(I)–halide coordination polymers have been prepared both by hydrothermal procedure and by using ambient conditions. Very often the synthetic procedure influences the nature of the obtained compounds in both structure and composition. From the crystal engineering perspective, along with the Cu­(I) coordination grids the mixed-valence Cu­(II)–Cu­(I) coordination networks are widely studied due to the different Cu­(I) and Cu­(II) (d10 and d9) coordination preferences that allow to manipulate the coordination architecture and dimensionalities of the final solids in view of the application requirements. The mixed-valence Cu­(II)–Cu­(I) compounds are obtained either starting from the mixture of Cu­(II)/Cu­(I) salts or by partial in situ reduction of Cu­(II).
elements.clean_text: Cu(I)-halide complexes are particularly attractive because of their promising optical properties and the ready obtainability of various building blocks. Cu(I)-halides react eagerly with nitrogen-donor ligands as a result of the soft-soft bonding preference, generating diverse geometries with various [CuX] n  structural motifs. Since seminal work by Blake et al. who reported a family of Cu(I) iodide coordination networks with different bidentate ligands including 1,10-phenanthroline, pyrazine, 4,4'-bipyride, this topic has attracted much interest from the crystal engineering perspective due to the variety of structural formats obtainable by using different halides and N-bases. Cu(I)-halide coordination polymers have been prepared both by hydrothermal procedure and by using ambient conditions. Very often the synthetic procedure influences the nature of the obtained compounds in both structure and composition. From the crystal engineering perspective, along with the Cu(I) coordination grids the mixed-valence Cu(II)-Cu(I) coordination networks are widely studied due to the different Cu(I) and Cu(II) (d10 and d9) coordination preferences that allow to manipulate the coordination architecture and dimensionalities of the final solids in view of the application requirements. The mixed-valence Cu(II)-Cu(I) compounds are obtained either starting from the mixture of Cu(II)/Cu(I) salts or by partial in situ reduction of Cu(II).

elements.content: Recently, research in the field of luminescent copper­(I) complexes has gained additional interest owing to their possible application in organic-light-emitting diodes (OLEDs) or light-emitting electrochemical cells (LEECs). Cu­(I) complexes, in fact, often exhibit thermally activated delayed fluorescence (TADF), which allows utilizing all injected excitons for the generation of light by making use of the singlet harvesting effect. In this regard, Cu­(I) complexes can provide a low-cost alternative to expensive emitters based on third row transition metals, such as platinum or iridium.
elements.clean_text: Recently, research in the field of luminescent copper(I) complexes has gained additional interest owing to their possible application in organic-light-emitting diodes (OLEDs) or light-emitting electrochemical cells (LEECs). Cu(I) complexes, in fact, often exhibit thermally activated delayed fluorescence (TADF), which allows utilizing all injected excitons for the generation of light by making use of the singlet harvesting effect. In this regard, Cu(I) complexes can provide a low-cost alternative to expensive emitters based on third row transition metals, such as platinum or iridium.

elements.content: This work was aimed at preparing and characterizing the missing member in the row of [CuIX­(pyz)] n complexes (X = Cl, Br, I) and to compare its photoluminescence behavior with that of the already known 4,4′-bipyridine analogue. We started from the in situ reduction of Cu­(II) salts in the presence of KI as a long-term recognized reducing agent. This approach resulted in the isolation of three new coordination compounds, [CuII­(pyz)] n , {[CuI(pyz)2]·I5} n , and {[CuII(NO3)­(bpy)2]·I3·(dmf·H2O)} n , which were characterized by IR spectroscopy and X-ray analysis. Photoluminescence spectroscopy was performed at both room and low temperature for [CuII­(pyz)] n , the only emissive of the three.
elements.clean_text: This work was aimed at preparing and characterizing the missing member in the row of [CuIX(pyz)] n  complexes (X = Cl, Br, I) and to compare its photoluminescence behavior with that of the already known 4,4'-bipyridine analogue. We started from the in situ reduction of Cu(II) salts in the presence of KI as a long-term recognized reducing agent. This approach resulted in the isolation of three new coordination compounds, [CuII(pyz)] n , {[CuI(pyz)2]⋅I5} n , and {[CuII(NO3)(bpy)2]⋅I3⋅(dmf⋅H2O)} n , which were characterized by IR spectroscopy and X-ray analysis. Photoluminescence spectroscopy was performed at both room and low temperature for [CuII(pyz)] n , the only emissive of the three.

elements.content: An acetonitrile solution of Cu­(NO3)2·3H2O, KI and pyrazine (pyz) (1:1:4 molar ratio) was refluxed for 30 min. The requested ratio of starting materials was determined empirically starting from 1:1:1 until crystalline product was observed. The yellow precipitate formed during the reaction was filtered off and washed with MeCN. The orange filtrate of the original solution was left in a covered vial for about one month giving two types of crystals, orange plates and dark blue blocks ().
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and X-ray Studies

Compounds Prepared from Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O/KI/Pyrazine

An acetonitrile solution of Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O, KI and pyrazine (pyz) (1:1:4 molar ratio) was refluxed for 30 min. The requested ratio of starting materials was determined empirically starting from 1:1:1 until crystalline product was observed. The yellow precipitate formed during the reaction was filtered off and washed with MeCN. The orange filtrate of the original solution was left in a covered vial for about one month giving two types of crystals, orange plates and dark blue blocks ().

elements.content: Solid CuI–pyrazine derivatives: (a) powder of yellow [(CuII)2(pyz)] n ; (b) orange crystals of [CuII­(pyz)] n ; (c) dark blue crystals of {[CuI(pyz)2]·I5} n .
elements.clean_text: 1  Solid CuI-pyrazine derivatives: (a) powder of yellow [(CuII)2(pyz)] n ; (b) orange crystals of [CuII(pyz)] n ; (c) dark blue crystals of {[CuI(pyz)2]⋅I5} n .

elements.content: The fine-crystalline yellow solid (a) was identified as the known [(CuII)2(pyz)] n having IR spectrum (Figure S1 in the Supporting Information) and XRPD pattern identical to that published for this compound. Single-crystal X-ray investigation undertaken for the orange (b) and dark (c) forms identify these solids as the new 2D neutral polymeric coordination network [CuII­(pyz)] n and the 3D cationic coordination network [CuI(pyz)2] n completed by noncoordinated pentaiodide anion in {[CuI(pyz)2]·I5} n .
elements.clean_text: The fine-crystalline yellow solid (a) was identified as the known [(CuII)2(pyz)] n  having IR spectrum (Figure S1 in the Supporting Information) and XRPD pattern identical to that published for this compound. Single-crystal X-ray investigation undertaken for the orange (b) and dark (c) forms identify these solids as the new 2D neutral polymeric coordination network [CuII(pyz)] n  and the 3D cationic coordination network [CuI(pyz)2] n  completed by noncoordinated pentaiodide anion in {[CuI(pyz)2]⋅I5} n .

elements.content: Compound [CuII­(pyz)] n crystallizes in the monoclinic P2/c space group (), and the asymmetric unit comprises halves of Cu­(I) cation, iodide anion, which reside on twofold axes, and a half of a centrosymmetric pyz molecule.
elements.clean_text: Compound [CuII(pyz)] n  crystallizes in the monoclinic P2/c space group (), and the asymmetric unit comprises halves of Cu(I) cation, iodide anion, which reside on twofold axes, and a half of a centrosymmetric pyz molecule.

The Cu­(I) atom adjusts the N2I2 distorted tetrahedral coordination core being linked with two iodide anions and two pyz molecules (a). The Cu–I and Cu–N distances are 2.6115(10), 2.6091(8) Å and 2.059(7), 2.056(1) Å, at room and low temperatures, respectively. The variation of bond angles at Cu atom in the range 105.66(19)–113.83(18)° (105.17(4)–115.26(4)° for LT data) indicates the distortion of tetrahedron, mostly due to difference in two N–Cu–I angles ().
elements.clean_text: The Cu(I) atom adjusts the N2I2 distorted tetrahedral coordination core being linked with two iodide anions and two pyz molecules (a). The Cu-I and Cu-N distances are 2.6115(10), 2.6091(8) Å and 2.059(7), 2.056(1) Å, at room and low temperatures, respectively. The variation of bond angles at Cu atom in the range 105.66(19)-113.83(18)° (105.17(4)-115.26(4)° for LT data) indicates the distortion of tetrahedron, mostly due to difference in two N-Cu-I angles ().

elements.content: The neutral 2D coordination network is built of the alternating Cu–I corrugated chains linked by pyz ligands. The Cu ... Cu separations within the layer are 4.267 and 6.918 Å through iodide and pyz bridges, respectively, and the shortest one between the layers is 6.881 Å. The corrugated layers are parallel to the ac crystallographic plane and stack along the crystallographic b direction. The comparison of the RT and LT data for [CuII­(pyz)] n (, ) shows the shortening of the unit cell parameters a and c along the layer, decreasing of the I–Cu–I, N–Cu–N, and Cu–I–Cu valence angles, and increasing the parameter b perpendicular to layers direction upon cooling (b). The compound is isostructural to the closest analogues, [CuCl­(pyz)] n and [CuBr­(pyz)] n . The related compound [(CuII)2(pyz)] n reveals the ladderlike (Cu2I2) n tape within the 2D network (c) instead of the chain.

The corrugated layers are parallel to the ac crystallographic plane and stack along the crystallographic b direction. The comparison of the RT and LT data for [CuII(pyz)] n  (, ) shows the shortening of the unit cell parameters a and c along the layer, decreasing of the I-Cu-I, N-Cu-N, and Cu-I-Cu valence angles, and increasing the parameter b perpendicular to layers direction upon cooling (b). The compound is isostructural to the closest analogues, [CuCl(pyz)] n   and [CuBr(pyz)] n . The related compound [(CuII)2(pyz)] n   reveals the ladderlike (Cu2I2) n  tape within the 2D network (c) instead of the chain.

elements.content: The third compound which coprecipitated almost simultaneously with [CuII­(pyz)] n crystallizes as big dark blue blocks with the metallic luster (c) belonging to the orthorhombic Fdd2 space group. It has been proven to be the 3D coordination polymer with {[CuI(pyz)2]·I5} n composition (). The asymmetric portion of the unit cell contains halves of the Cu­(I) atom and pentaiodide anion, which reside on the twofold axis, and one pyz ligand in general position. In the four-connected 3D diamondoid cationic network, Cu­(I) cation coordinates four bridging pyz ligands and adjusts the N4-distorted tetrahedral geometry, with Cu–Nav = 2.025(10) Å, and N–Cu–N angles in the wide range of 98.2(4)–120.2(6)°.
elements.clean_text: The third compound which coprecipitated almost simultaneously with [CuII(pyz)] n  crystallizes as big dark blue blocks with the metallic luster (c) belonging to the orthorhombic Fdd2 space group. It has been proven to be the 3D coordination polymer with {[CuI(pyz)2]⋅I5} n  composition (). The asymmetric portion of the unit cell contains halves of the Cu(I) atom and pentaiodide anion, which reside on the twofold axis, and one pyz ligand in general position. In the four-connected 3D diamondoid cationic network, Cu(I) cation coordinates four bridging pyz ligands and adjusts the N4-distorted tetrahedral geometry, with Cu-Nav = 2.025(10) Å, and N-Cu-N angles in the wide range of 98.2(4)-120.2(6)°.

elements.content:
There are only three examples of pyz-bridged four-connected 3D networks: one with similar diamondoid-like sqc6 topology and two with different sqc182 and qtz network topologies.

Thus, the partial in situ reduction of Cu­(II) in the presence of KI resulted in one-pot synthesis of three Cu­(I) coordination polymers representing yellow [(CuII)2(pyz)] n and orange [CuII­(pyz)] n 2D networks and dark blue {[CuI(pyz)2]·I5} n 3D coordination grid.

elements.content: The use of bpy instead of pyz resulted in successive precipitation of the known yellow [(CuII)2(bpy)] n 2D coordination polymer confirmed by the IR spectrum and X-ray powder diffraction pattern and new brown 3D coordination polymer {[CuII(NO3)­(bpy)2]·I3·(dmf·H2O)} n in which the Cu­(II) cations are not affected by the reduction (). Starting from either Cu­(CH3COO)2·H2O or Cu­(BF4)2, the known yellow [(CuII)2(bpy)] n and orange [CuII­(bpy)] n forms precipitated successively.
elements.clean_text:
Compounds Prepared from Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O/KI/4,4'-bipyridine

The use of bpy instead of pyz resulted in successive precipitation of the known yellow [(CuII)2(bpy)] n  2D coordination polymer confirmed by the IR spectrum and X-ray powder diffraction pattern and new brown 3D coordination polymer {[CuII(NO3)(bpy)2]⋅I3⋅(dmf⋅H2O)} n  in which the Cu(II) cations are not affected by the reduction (). Starting from either Cu(CH3COO)2⋅H2O or Cu(BF4)2, the known yellow [(CuII)2(bpy)] n  and orange [CuII(bpy)] n   forms precipitated successively.

elements.content: Solid Cu–4,4′-bipyridine derivatives: (a) yellow [(CuII)2(bpy)] n ; (b) brown crystals of {[CuII(NO3)­(bpy)2]·I3·(dmf·H2O)} n .
elements.clean_text: 4  Solid Cu-4,4'-bipyridine derivatives: (a) yellow [(CuII)2(bpy)] n ; (b) brown crystals of {[CuII(NO3)(bpy)2]⋅I3⋅(dmf⋅H2O)} n .

elements.content: The brown 3D Cu­(II) coordination polymer () crystallizes in the orthorhombic Cmca space group, and the asymmetric unit consists of halves of one Cu­(II) ion and two halves of two symmetry independent bpy molecules, which reside on twofold axes, halves of one nitrate anion and I3 – anion located on mirror plane, and disordered dmf and water molecules. The square-bipyramidal Cu­(II) coordination core formulated as N4O2 goes from four bpy ligands in the equatorial plane with the Cu–N distances in the range 2.001(6)–2.027(5) Å and two NO3 – anions in axial positions with the Cu–O distance of 2.359(5) Å (). The bidentate bpy molecules and NO3 – anions bridge Cu­(II) cations in the 3D cationic open framework with rectangular cells, having 11.112 × 11.094 × 6.845 Å dimensions calculated as the distances between the Cu­(II) atoms in the vertexes of cells through bpy ligands and NO3 – anions in the directions parallel to the c, b, and a crystallographic axes, respectively. Atoms of cationic framework occupy 45% of the crystal space, and the remaining 55.0% of the unit cell volume are filled with the I3 – anions and the disordered solvents, which are dmf and water molecules.

Atoms of cationic framework occupy 45% of the crystal space, and the remaining 55.0% of the unit cell volume are filled with the I3 - anions and the disordered solvents, which are dmf and water molecules.

elements.content: While the cationic square-grid {CuII(bpy)2} n 2D coordination framework is reported in a series of coordination polymers with the weakly bound anions occupying the Cu­(II) axial positions, or with outer sphere anions (including the weakly bound nitrate anion as well), the reported framework may be viewed as pillar-layered 3D structure, where the NO3 – pillars unite these grids into 3D coordination network. To the best of our knowledge only one such example is known so far where the NO3 – and PF6 – anions alternate as the pillars in the 3D coordination grid.
elements.clean_text: While the cationic square-grid {CuII(bpy)2} n  2D coordination framework is reported in a series of coordination polymers with the weakly bound anions occupying the Cu(II) axial positions, or with outer sphere anions (including the weakly bound nitrate anion as well), the reported framework may be viewed as pillar-layered 3D structure, where the NO3 - pillars unite these grids into 3D coordination network. To the best of our knowledge only one such example is known so far where the NO3 - and PF6 - anions alternate as the pillars in the 3D coordination grid.

elements.content: Summarizing our crystallographic studies, in the Cu­(NO3)·3H2O/KI/pyz system, the two novel polymers, viz. [CuII­(pyz)] n and {[CuI(pyz)2]·I5} n , are formed along with known [(CuII)2(pyz)] n compound. When the bpy has been used in this reaction (instead of pyz), the precipitation of known 2D coordination polymer, [(CuII)2(bpy)] n , and new 3D polymer, {[CuII(NO3)­(bpy)2]·I3·(dmf·H2O)} n , the Cu­(II) atom of which remains unreduced, is observed. Moreover, interaction of Cu­(CH3COO)2·H2O or Cu­(BF4)2 with bpy and KI leads to the known [(CuII)2(bpy)] n and [CuII­(bpy)] n polymers, with a complete reduction of Cu­(II) to Cu­(I). Since in situ reduction of Cu­(II) to Cu­(I) is a very sensitive process affected by several factors such as solvent, anion, base, and reducing agent, it is rather difficult to underline the decisive factors responsible for the complete conversion of Cu­(II) to Cu­(I) in the examined pyz and bpy systems. Nevertheless, most probably, for the first system the high affinity of Cu­(I) to pyz and MeCN, which stabilizes Cu­(I), results in exclusively Cu­(I) compounds. For the second one, the formation of Cu­(II) or Cu­(I) complexes, depending on the used counterion, could be explained by the fact that BF4 – and CH3COO– act as easy-leaving anions, while NO3 – remains attached to the Cu­(II) center. Moreover, the solvent mixture, DMF and MeCN, necessary to provide the solubility of starting salts, is less favorable for stabilization of Cu­(I).
elements.clean_text: Summarizing our crystallographic studies, in the Cu(NO3)⋅3H2O/KI/pyz system, the two novel polymers, viz. [CuII(pyz)] n  and {[CuI(pyz)2]⋅I5} n , are formed along with known [(CuII)2(pyz)] n  compound. When the bpy has been used in this reaction (instead of pyz), the precipitation of known 2D coordination polymer, [(CuII)2(bpy)] n , and new 3D polymer, {[CuII(NO3)(bpy)2]⋅I3⋅(dmf⋅H2O)} n , the Cu(II) atom of which remains unreduced, is observed. Moreover, interaction of Cu(CH3COO)2⋅H2O or Cu(BF4)2 with bpy and KI leads to the known [(CuII)2(bpy)] n  and [CuII(bpy)] n  polymers, with a complete reduction of Cu(II) to Cu(I). Since in situ reduction of Cu(II) to Cu(I) is a very sensitive process affected by several factors such as solvent, anion, base, and reducing agent, it is rather difficult to underline the decisive factors responsible for the complete conversion of Cu(II) to Cu(I) in the examined pyz and bpy systems. Nevertheless, most probably, for the first system the high affinity of Cu(I) to pyz and MeCN, which stabilizes Cu(I), results in exclusively Cu(I) compounds. For the second one, the formation of Cu(II) or Cu(I) complexes, depending on the used counterion, could be explained by the fact that BF4 - and CH3COO- act as easy-leaving anions, while NO3 - remains attached to the Cu(II) center. Moreover, the solvent mixture, DMF and MeCN, necessary to provide the solubility of starting salts, is less favorable for stabilization of Cu(I).

elements.content: To compare the easiness of the iodine release from two 3D coordination networks, the crystals of {[CuI(pyz)2]·I5} n and {[CuII(NO3)­(bpy)2]·I3·(dmf·H2O)} n that contain polyiodide anions were soaked in a methanol solution (). The gradual coloring of organic layer and bleaching of the crystals occurred differently. From solid {[CuI(pyz)2]·I5} n the portion of iodine is easily and immediately extracted by the methanol solution, and dark blue crystal blocks then were transforming into the colorless ones. Our attempts to run the X-ray single-crystal experiment on these blocks failed due to the lack of the diffraction pattern. Thus, we conclude the structure-directing function of the I5 – template that occupies approximately 56.2% or 2037.74 Å3 of the unit cell volume. Contrarily, the iodine release occurred slowly from crystals of {[CuII(NO3)­(bpy)2]·I3·(dmf·H2O)} n , which retained their crystallinity as it was indicated by the repeated single-crystal X-ray diffraction measurements from the partially bleaching crystals that reproduce the same unit cell dimensions. The changes in the channels’ content are currently under investigation in our laboratory. Such differences in the stability of the two frameworks were also evident in the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) as shown in Figure S2. The TGA for {[CuI(pyz)2]·I5} n revealed two-step release of iodine (182.5 and 280.0 °C) (73.93% calc) with the consequent collapse of the 3D framework completed at 489.3 °C. A more complicated degradation process was observed for {[CuII(NO3)­(bpy)2]·I3·(dmf·H2O)} n whose framework remains stable up to 264.5 °C. The TGA curve indicates a weight loss of 52.23% which can be attributed to the loss of guest dmf and water molecules and release of iodine (51.88% calc). A weight loss of 88.9% in the interval 260–488 °C is associated with the collapse of the 3D grid.

The gradual coloring of organic layer and bleaching of the crystals occurred differently. From solid {[CuI(pyz)2]⋅I5} n  the portion of iodine is easily and immediately extracted by the methanol solution, and dark blue crystal blocks then were transforming into the colorless ones. elements.clean_text:
Luminescence Studies

We have determined the photoluminescence behavior of four solid samples, [(CuI) x (B)] n  x = 1, 2, B = pyz, bpy (Figures S3-S16). The results (emission maxima, quantum yields, and lifetimes) are reported, together with available literature data, in .

Particularly relevant is the elusive [CuII­(pyz)] n which fills the gap in the structural characterization of [CuIX­(pyz)] n (X = Cl, Br, I) 2D coordination polymers. For what concerns the photoluminescence properties of this triad, those of [CuIBr­(pyz)] n have been reported in two papers while, to the best of our knowledge, those of [CuICl­(pyz)] n are missing maybe because it lacks any observable emission as is the case for several chloride derivatives.
elements.clean_text: Particularly relevant is the elusive [CuII(pyz)] n  which fills the gap in the structural characterization of [CuIX(pyz)] n  (X = Cl, Br, I) 2D coordination polymers. For what concerns the photoluminescence properties of this triad, those of [CuIBr(pyz)] n  have been reported in two papers while, to the best of our knowledge, those of [CuICl(pyz)] n  are missing maybe because it lacks any observable emission as is the case for several chloride derivatives.

elements.content: Crystals of [CuII­(pyz)] n display bright emission (centered at 639 nm, τ = 0.54 (39%), 3.32 (61%) μs, Φ equal to 2.7) at room temperature which can be assigned to a mixed halide-to-ligand and metal-to-ligand charge transfer (XL/MLCT) excited state ( ). In fact, the shortest Cu ... Cu separation (4.267 Å) is much longer than that required to generate a cluster-centered excited state of d–s character (3CC). Moreover, DFT calculations on a model fragment, [(CuII)2(pyz)2(CuII)2] (see Figure S17), reveal that the HOMO and the other occupied MOs around the HOMO are mainly composed of I-4p and Cu-3d orbitals. The LUMO and the nonoccupied orbitals close to it are essentially pyz π* orbitals (see and S18 for a plot of the frontier orbitals). Though the lowest-energy transition was calculated by TD-DFT at 566 nm (oscillator strength f = 0.0013), the first significant excitation was obtained at 507 nm (f = 0.070), in close agreement with the band observed at about 520 nm in the excitation spectrum (see Figure S3). Both transitions involve several configurations all showing XL/MLCT character (see Table S1 for the full set of excitation energies and assignments). Calculations then support the fact that the emission of [CuI­(pyz)] n originates from an excited state of mixed XL/MLCT character. The same attribution was made for the analogous [CuBr­(pyz)] n derivative. For this compound an emission at 648 nm (τ = 0.20 (67%), 1.19 (33%) μs) or at 629 nm (τ = 62.9 ns) was reported at room temperature (at 77 K the emission is red-shifted at 690 nm, τ = 8 μs or 644 nm respectively). The almost independent position of the emission from the halide’s polarizability or the ionization potentials (648–629 vs 639 nm for X = Br or I, respectively) does not contrast the XLCT contribution to such emission. Such behavior was, in fact, already encountered for other Cu­(I) derivatives for which it was found from ab initio calculations that the coordinated iodine is less negatively charged than chlorine, thus compensating for the lower ionization potential of the former. Moreover, a large structural relaxation in the photoexcited state could be large enough to cancel out the marginal difference of the HOMO–LUMO gap in the ground state as previously reported.

elements.content: Cu­(I) complexes with transitions of charge transfer nature are often characterized by small energy separations between the lowest singlet S1 and triplet T1 state so that thermally activated delayed fluorescence (TADF) and, if applied to electroluminescent devices, singlet harvesting can become highly effective. Efficient TADF essentially requires small energy separations ΔE(S1–T1) with preference below about 1000 cm–1 (≈120 meV). This is achievable with complexes that exhibit small spatial HOMO–LUMO overlap. For energy separations below 300 cm–1 (≈37 meV), short radiative TADF decay times of less than 5 μs can be observed.
elements.clean_text: Cu(I) complexes with transitions of charge transfer nature are often characterized by small energy separations between the lowest singlet S1 and triplet T1 state so that thermally activated delayed fluorescence (TADF) and, if applied to electroluminescent devices, singlet harvesting can become highly effective. Efficient TADF essentially requires small energy separations ΔE(S1-T1) with preference below about 1000 cm-1 (~120 meV). This is achievable with complexes that exhibit small spatial HOMO-LUMO overlap. For energy separations below 300 cm-1 (~37 meV), short radiative TADF decay times of less than 5 μs can be observed.

elements.content: To check if TADF mechanism is involved in the luminescent behavior of solid [CuII­(pyz)] n , we have examined its emissive properties at 77 K. Upon cooling, the emission is slightly (≈24 nm, 70 meV) red-shifted (663 nm) and the lifetime becomes three times longer (τ = 12 μs). Based on these, we suggest that the room temperature shortest component can be attributed to fluorescence while the longer one, shorter than what would be expected for phosphorescence (10–1000 μs), can be ascribed to TADF. At low temperature the probability of the thermally activated T1 → S1 conversion is decreased reflecting the increase of the lifetime up to 12 μs, which is characteristic of phosphorescence. The lifetime values and the energy differences between room and low temperature are compatible with TADF and are close to that observed for other Cu­(I) coordination polymers for which the TADF mechanism has been proposed. This interpretation is supported by TDDFT calculations, which provide a vertical (i.e., without considering geometry relaxation of excited states) ΔE(S1–T1) energy gap of 0.14 eV.

Based on these, we suggest that the room temperature shortest component can be attributed to fluorescence while the longer one, shorter than what would be expected for phosphorescence (10-1000 μs), can be ascribed to TADF. At low temperature the probability of the thermally activated T1 → S1 conversion is decreased reflecting the increase of the lifetime up to 12 μs, which is characteristic of phosphorescence. The lifetime values and the energy differences between room and low temperature are compatible with TADF and are close to that observed for other Cu(I) coordination polymers for which the TADF mechanism has been proposed. This interpretation is supported by TDDFT calculations, which provide a vertical (i.e., without considering geometry relaxation of excited states) ΔE(S1-T1) energy gap of 0.14 eV.

elements.content: Emissive behavior of [(CuII)2(bpy)] n and [CuII­(bpy)] n is in agreement with previous findings and substantiate a XMCT as dominating transition. In addition, the short room temperature lifetimes indicate only a fluorescent character of the emission. More interestingly, preliminary results indicate for the latter a mechanochromic behavior upon grinding. A color change from orange to yellow and an increase in the emission intensity (Figure S7) are observed that most probably are connected with the solid state transformation of the coordination polymer which deserves further investigation.
elements.clean_text: Emissive behavior of [(CuII)2(bpy)] n  and [CuII(bpy)] n  is in agreement with previous findings and substantiate a XMCT as dominating transition. In addition, the short room temperature lifetimes indicate only a fluorescent character of the emission. More interestingly, preliminary results indicate for the latter a mechanochromic behavior upon grinding. A color change from orange to yellow and an increase in the emission intensity (Figure S7) are observed that most probably are connected with the solid state transformation of the coordination polymer which deserves further investigation.

elements.content: Luminescent properties of [(CuII)2(pyz)] n have already been investigated independently by Pospisil et al. and, more recently, by Khatri et al. These latter authors suggest a TADF mechanism of the emission even if a large and hypsochromic shift is displayed at 77 K. Our spectroscopic studies, even though giving emission maxima quite different from those reported by Khatri (but similar to those observed by Pospisil), support this hypothesis. In fact a very small bathochromic shift and a more than seven times longer lifetime (calculated on the longer component) is measured when going from r.t. (582 nm; τ = 1.8 μs) to 77 K (593 nm; τ = 12.7 μs) (see ).

elements.content: All reagents and solvents were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. Elemental analyses were performed on an ElementarAnalysensysteme GmbH Vario El III elemental analyzer. The IR spectra were obtained in KBr pellets on a FT IR Spectrum-100 PerkinElmer spectrometer in the range of 400–4000 cm–1.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All reagents and solvents were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. Elemental analyses were performed on an ElementarAnalysensysteme GmbH Vario El III elemental analyzer. The IR spectra were obtained in KBr pellets on a FT IR Spectrum-100 PerkinElmer spectrometer in the range of 400-4000 cm-1.

elements.content: Thermal behaviors of the complexes have been studied by thermogravimetric (TG), derivative weight loss (DTG), and differential thermal analyses (DTA) in air atmosphere. Thermal analysis was performed on a Derivatograph Q-1500 system. Each sample (about 20 mg) was placed in a platinum crucible and was heated under air flow rate of 100 mL/min and a heating rate of 10 °C/min from 20 to 1050 °C. TG, DTG, and DTA curves were simultaneously registered.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Analysis

Thermal behaviors of the complexes have been studied by thermogravimetric (TG), derivative weight loss (DTG), and differential thermal analyses (DTA) in air atmosphere. Thermal analysis was performed on a Derivatograph Q-1500 system. Each sample (about 20 mg) was placed in a platinum crucible and was heated under air flow rate of 100 mL/min and a heating rate of 10 °C/min from 20 to 1050 °C. TG, DTG, and DTA curves were simultaneously registered.

elements.content: Photoluminescence quantum yields were measured using a C11347 Quantaurus-Absolute Photoluminescence Quantum Yield Spectrometer (Hamamatsu Photonics K.K), equipped with a 150 W xenon lamp, an integrating sphere, and a multichannel detector.

elements.content: Steady state emission and excitation spectra and photoluminescence lifetimes were obtained using a FLS 980 spectrofluorimeter (Edinburg Instrument Ltd.). The steady state measurements were obtained by a 450 W xenon arc lamp. Photoluminescence lifetime measurements were performed using both Edinburgh Picosecond Pulsed Diode Laser EPL-445 (Edinburg Instrument Ltd.) and microsecond flash Xe-lamp (60 W, 0.1÷100 Hz) with data acquisition devices time-correlated single-photon counting (TCSPC) and multichannel scaling (MCS) methods, respectively.

elements.content: Single-crystal diffraction measurements for [(CuII) (pyz)] n , {[CuI(pyz)2]·I5} n , [CuII­(bpy)] n , and {[CuII(NO3)­(bpy)2]·I3·(dmf·H2O)} n were carried out on an Xcalibur E diffractometer equipped with a CCD area detector and a graphite monochromator utilizing MoKα radiation at a room temperature. Additionally the low-temperature experiment for [CuII­(pyz)] n was run at 130 K on a Bruker SMART APEX-II CCD area-detector diffractometer equipped with an Oxford Cryosystems Cryostream 700Plus cryostat. Final unit cell dimensions were obtained and refined on an entire data set. All calculations to solve the structures, and to refine the models proposed were carried out with the programs SHELXS97 and SHELXL2014. Hydrogen atoms attached to carbon atoms were positioned geometrically and treated as riding atoms using SHELXL default parameters with U iso(H) = 1.2U eq(C). In {[CuII(NO3)­(bpy)2]·I3·(dmf·H2O)} n disordered solvent molecules and the minor position of NO3 anion were refined in isotropic approximation; the H atoms in water molecules were not located. The X-ray data and the details of the refinement for [CuII­(pyz)] n , [CuI (pyz)2I5] n , and {[CuII(NO3)­(bpy)2]·I3·(dmf·H2O)} n are summarized in ; selected geometric parameters are summarized in . The figures were produced using Mercury.

elements.content:
X-ray powder patterns were recorded on a Philips PW1820 diffractometer (Cu–Kα radiation, λ = l.5405 Å) in the 5–40° 2θ range (0.02° and 1.5 s per step).

Computational Details

Computational studies have been performed on a discrete model of the [CuII­(pyz)] n polymeric structure, [(CuII)2(pyz)2(CuII)2], comprising two (CuI)2 chains and two pyrazine molecules interconnecting the (CuII)2 chains (see Figure S17), using the Gaussian 09 suite of programs. The geometry of the fragment has been optimized at the M06-2X/6-311++G­(d,p) level of theory starting from the 130 K X-ray structure, freezing angles and torsions to preserve the correct coordination geometry around the copper ions. The basis set for iodine was downloaded from the Basis Set Exchange site. The M06-2X functional has been chosen in view of its optimal performance in treating noncovalent interactions, which in the present structure revealed to be important owing to the short distance between adjacent pyrazine rings. Their interplanar distance (3.441 Å in the low-temperature (130 K) X-ray crystal structure) would suggest in fact π–π stacking interaction. For the same reason, a large basis set including diffuse functions has been chosen. In the final structure, the pyrazine rings kept essentially unvaried their parallel arrangement, with interplanar distance equal to 3.416 Å. The Cu–I bond lengths were slightly shorter for the iodine atoms external to the chain with respect to the internal one (2.48–2.58 vs 2.63–2.67 Å, respectively), and the Cu···Cu separation was 4.22 Å, in very good agreement with the X-ray values (2.609 and 4.247 Å, respectively). The Cu–N bond lengths, on the other hand, showed a rather wide range of variability (from 2.08 to 2.21 Å) and were longer than the experimental value, 2.057 Å. Following the computational protocol previously developed to treat organic emitters showing TADF, TDDFT calculations have been performed on the optimized ground state structure using the range-separated LC-ωPBE* functional with ω = 0.30 to obtain both the lowest singlet (S1) and triplet (T1) excited states determining the “vertical” ΔE ST energy gap. The choice of the ω value, in place of the default one (0.40), was based on its better performance in reproducing the experimental lowest-energy transition. All excited state calculations were performed with the same 6-311++G­(d,p) basis set used for ground state calculations.

Computational Details

Computational studies have been performed on a discrete model of the [CuII(pyz)] n  polymeric structure, [(CuII)2(pyz)2(CuII)2], comprising two (CuI)2 chains and two pyrazine molecules interconnecting the (CuII)2 chains (see Figure S17), using the Gaussian 09 suite of programs. The basis set for iodine was downloaded from the Basis Set Exchange site. The M06-2X functional has been chosen in view of its optimal performance in treating noncovalent interactions, which in the present structure revealed to be important owing to the short distance between adjacent pyrazine rings. Their interplanar distance (3.441 Å in the low-temperature (130 K) X-ray crystal structure) would suggest in fact π-π stacking interaction. For the same reason, a large basis set including diffuse functions has been chosen. In the final structure, the pyrazine rings kept essentially unvaried their parallel arrangement, with interplanar distance equal to 3.416 Å. The Cu-I bond lengths were slightly shorter for the iodine atoms external to the chain with respect to the internal one (2.48-2.58 vs 2.63-2.67 Å, respectively), and the Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu separation was 4.22 Å, in very good agreement with the X-ray values (2.609 and 4.247 Å, respectively). The Cu-N bond lengths, on the other hand, showed a rather wide range of variability (from 2.08 to 2.21 Å) and were longer than the experimental value, 2.057 Å. Following the computational protocol previously developed to treat organic emitters showing TADF, TDDFT calculations have been performed on the optimized ground state structure using the range-separated LC-ωPBE* functional with ω = 0.30 to obtain both the lowest singlet (S1) and triplet (T1) excited states determining the "vertical" ΔE ST energy gap. The choice of the ω value, in place of the default one (0.40), was based on its better performance in reproducing the experimental lowest-energy transition. All excited state calculations were performed with the same 6-311++G(d,p) basis set used for ground state calculations.

elements.content: The partial in situ reduction of Cu­(II) in the presence of KI and pyrazine (pyz) resulted in two two-dimensional and one three-dimensional Cu­(I) coordination networks including the so-far elusive orange [CuII­(pyz)] n that represents the missing member in the row of two-dimensional coordination networks of general formula [CuIX­(pyz)] n (X = Cl, Br, I). When the 4,4′-bipyridine (bpy) has been used in this reaction (instead of pyz), the precipitated products include the known Cu­(I) 2D polymers, [(CuII) x (bpy)] n (x = 1, 2), and the new Cu­(II) 3D coordination polymer, {[CuII(NO3)­(bpy)2]·I3·(dmf·H2O)} n . Powders of [CuII­(pyz)] n display TADF behavior associated with a small (M/XLCT) singlet–triplet splitting.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

The partial in situ reduction of Cu(II) in the presence of KI and pyrazine (pyz) resulted in two two-dimensional and one three-dimensional Cu(I) coordination networks including the so-far elusive orange [CuII(pyz)] n  that represents the missing member in the row of two-dimensional coordination networks of general formula [CuIX(pyz)] n  (X = Cl, Br, I). When the 4,4'-bipyridine (bpy) has been used in this reaction (instead of pyz), the precipitated products include the known Cu(I) 2D polymers, [(CuII) x (bpy)] n  (x = 1, 2), and the new Cu(II) 3D coordination polymer, {[CuII(NO3)(bpy)2]⋅I3⋅(dmf⋅H2O)} n . Powders of [CuII(pyz)] n  display TADF behavior associated with a small (M/XLCT) singlet-triplet splitting.

IR (KBr)/cm–1 for [(CuII)­(bpy)] n : 3072 sh, 3040 m, 3019 sh, 2601 w, 2456 w, 1944 w, 1723 w, 1688 w, 1598 m, 1527 m, 1482 m, 1414 sh, 1405 s, 1322 w, 1288 w, 1213 m, 1068 w, 1060 w, 1042 w, 1004 w, 965 w, 854 m, 814 sh, 797 vs, 743 w, 723 m, 672 w.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis

[(CuII)2(pyz)] n , [CuII(pyz)] n , and {[CuI(pyz)2]⋅I5} n  

The acetonitrile solution (5 mL) of Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O (0.06 g, 0.24 mmol), KI (0.04g, 0.24 mmol), and pyrazine (0.08 g, 0.99 mmol) was refluxed for 30 min. The yellow precipitate that formed during the reaction was filtered off and washed with MeCN, yield: 0.021 g (36.84%). Analyzing its IR and X-ray powder diffraction data (Figure S19), it corresponds to the published complex [(CuII)2(pyz)] n.  The orange filtrate of the original solution was left in a covered vial for about 1 month that gives two types of crystals: orange plates that correspond to the complex [CuII(pyz)] n  (yield: 0.019 g, 28.35%), anal. calcd for C4H4Cu1I1N2 C, 17.76; H, 1.49; N, 10.35; found: C, 17.78; H, 1.46; N, 10.31, and dark brown blocks that correspond to the complex {[CuI(pyz)2]⋅I5} n  (yield: 0.026 g, 12.2%). Anal. Calcd for C8H8Cu1I5N4: C, 11.2; H, 0.94; N, 6.53. Found: C, 11.24; H, 0.96; N, 6.51. IR (KBr)/cm-1 for [CuII(pyz)] n : 3674 m, 2988 s, 2973 sh, 2901 sh, 1929 w, 1871 w, 1753 w, 1697 w, 1616 w, 1583 w, 1484 w, 1452 w, 1414 m, 1394 sh, 1383 sh, 1303 w, 1250 m, 1241 sh, 1230 sh, 1157 w, 1075 sh, 1066 sh, 1055 vs, 1028 sh, 892 m, 880 sh, 869 sh, 795 m, 789 sh. IR (KBr)/cm-1 for {[CuI(pyz)2]⋅I5} n : 3676 m, 3661 sh, 3087 w, 3068 sh, 2988 m, 2972 sh, 2901 sh, 2638 w, 1943 w, 1877 w, 1813 w, 1774 w, 1714 w, 1648 w, 1617 w, 1475 m, 1406 vs, 1356 sh, 1250 m, 1242 sh, 1230 sh, 1150 m, 1112 m, 1073 sh, 1046 vs, 1028 sh, 978 w, 892 w, 868 w, 799 s.

[(CuII)2(bpy)] n  and {[CuII(NO3)(bpy)2]⋅I3⋅(dmf⋅H2O)} n  

A solution of 5 mL of MeCN and 3 mL of DMF containing Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O (0.06 g, 0.24 mmol), KI (0.04 g, 0.24 mmol), and 4,4'- bipyridine (0.04 g, 0.25 mmol) was refluxed for 30 min. The yellow precipitate formed during the reaction was filtered off and washed with MeCN, yield: 0.03 g (45.4%). Analyzing its IR and X-ray powder diffraction data (Figure S19), it corresponds to the published complex [(CuII)2(bpy)] n.  The orange filtrate of the original solution was left in a covered vial for about 2 weeks to give brown crystals of [CuII(NO3)(bpy)I3] n ⋅(dmf⋅H2O) n  (yield: 0.036 g, 16.3%). Anal. Calcd for C23H25CuI3N6O5: C, 30.37; H, 2.77; N, 9.24. Found: C, 30.34; H, 2.74; N, 9.26. IR (KBr)/cm-1: 3385 w, 3097 w, 3042 w, 2924 w, 1763 w, 1665 s, 1612 s, 1537 m, 1491 m, 1413 sh, 1375 sh, 1340 vs, 1315 sh, 1220 m, 1100 w, 1088 w, 1068 m, 1017 m, 854 w, 814 s, 797 sh, 726 w, 662 w.

[(CuII)2(bpy)] n  and [CuII(bpy)] n  

A solution of MeCN (5 mL) and DMF (3 mL) containing Cu(CH3COO)2⋅H2O (0.06g, 0.24 mmol), KI (0.04g, 0.24 mmol), and 4,4'-bipyridine (0.04 g, 0.25 mmol) was refluxed for 30 min. The yellow precipitate formed during the reaction was filtered off and washed with MeCN, yield: 0.02g (22.7%). Analyzing its X-ray powder diffraction data (Figure S19) it corresponds to the published complex [(CuII)2(bpy)] n.  The orange filtrate of the original solution was left in a covered vial for about 2 weeks to give red crystals of [(CuII)(bpy)] n   (yield: 0.034 g (29.8%). IR (KBr)/cm-1 for [(CuII)(bpy)] n : 3072 sh, 3040 m, 3019 sh, 2601 w, 2456 w, 1944 w, 1723 w, 1688 w, 1598 m, 1527 m, 1482 m, 1414 sh, 1405 s, 1322 w, 1288 w, 1213 m, 1068 w, 1060 w, 1042 w, 1004 w, 965 w, 854 m, 814 sh, 797 vs, 743 w, 723 m, 672 w.

cln_elements.content: To compare the easiness of the iodine release from two 3D coordination networks, the crystals of {[CuI(pyz)2]·I5} n and {[CuII(NO3)­(bpy)2]·I3·(dmf·H2O)} n that contain polyiodide anions were soaked in a methanol solution (). The gradual coloring of organic layer and bleaching of the crystals occurred differently. From solid {[CuI(pyz)2]·I5} n the portion of iodine is easily and immediately extracted by the methanol solution, and dark blue crystal blocks then were transforming into the colorless ones. Our attempts to run the X-ray single-crystal experiment on these blocks failed due to the lack of the diffraction pattern. Thus, we conclude the structure-directing function of the I5 – template that occupies approximately 56.2% or 2037.74 Å3 of the unit cell volume. Contrarily, the iodine release occurred slowly from crystals of {[CuII(NO3)­(bpy)2]·I3·(dmf·H2O)} n , which retained their crystallinity as it was indicated by the repeated single-crystal X-ray diffraction measurements from the partially bleaching crystals that reproduce the same unit cell dimensions. The changes in the channels’ content are currently under investigation in our laboratory. Such differences in the stability of the two frameworks were also evident in the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) as shown in Figure S2. The TGA for {[CuI(pyz)2]·I5} n revealed two-step release of iodine (182.5 and 280.0 °C) (73.93% calc) with the consequent collapse of the 3D framework completed at 489.3 °C. A more complicated degradation process was observed for {[CuII(NO3)­(bpy)2]·I3·(dmf·H2O)} n whose framework remains stable up to 264.5 °C. The TGA curve indicates a weight loss of 52.23% which can be attributed to the loss of guest dmf and water molecules and release of iodine (51.88% calc). A weight loss of 88.9% in the interval 260–488 °C is associated with the collapse of the 3D grid.
cln_elements.clean_text: To compare the easiness of the iodine release from two 3D coordination networks, the crystals of {[CuI(pyz)2]⋅I5} n  and {[CuII(NO3)(bpy)2]⋅I3⋅(dmf⋅H2O)} n  that contain polyiodide anions were soaked in a methanol solution (). The gradual coloring of organic layer and bleaching of the crystals occurred differently. From solid {[CuI(pyz)2]⋅I5} n  the portion of iodine is easily and immediately extracted by the methanol solution, and dark blue crystal blocks then were transforming into the colorless ones. Our attempts to run the X-ray single-crystal experiment on these blocks failed due to the lack of the diffraction pattern. Thus, we conclude the structure-directing function of the I5 - template that occupies approximately 56.2% or 2037.74 Å3 of the unit cell volume. Contrarily, the iodine release occurred slowly from crystals of {[CuII(NO3)(bpy)2]⋅I3⋅(dmf⋅H2O)} n , which retained their crystallinity as it was indicated by the repeated single-crystal X-ray diffraction measurements from the partially bleaching crystals that reproduce the same unit cell dimensions. The changes in the channels' content are currently under investigation in our laboratory. Such differences in the stability of the two frameworks were also evident in the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) as shown in Figure S2. The TGA for {[CuI(pyz)2]⋅I5} n  revealed two-step release of iodine (182.5 and 280.0 °C) (73.93% calc) with the consequent collapse of the 3D framework completed at 489.3 °C. A more complicated degradation process was observed for {[CuII(NO3)(bpy)2]⋅I3⋅(dmf⋅H2O)} n  whose framework remains stable up to 264.5 °C. The TGA curve indicates a weight loss of 52.23% which can be attributed to the loss of guest dmf and water molecules and release of iodine (51.88% calc). A weight loss of 88.9% in the interval 260-488 °C is associated with the collapse of the 3D grid.
